docs.lead_paragraph: As a dog lover and dog owner for 70 years, who prefers 100-percent boxers, I find the concept of designer dogs to be ludicrous (Jon Mooallem, Feb. 4). Certainly, purebreds may be overly inbred and hindered by genetic deficits, and two different breeds may produce an affectionate and even attractive dog. But to claim that a Morkie will have “the smartness of the Yorkie and the sweetness of the Maltese,” rather than the bossiness of the Yorkie and the obtuseness of the Maltese, is wishful thinking. George Bernard Shaw was once propositioned by a woman who wrote that their offspring would have his brains and her beauty. Shaw was said to have replied, “What if the child has my looks and your brains?”.

docs.lead_paragraph: A GROWING industry is hoping to spin gold from DNA's double helixes by using ultrasensitive genetic tests to personalize medical treatment for cancer, lupus and other diseases. These molecular diagnostic tests can give doctors more detailed information than ever about their patients. Genetic information can help them decide whether their lymphoma patients would respond better to surgery, chemotherapy or radiation treatment; make more accurate diagnoses of abnormal cells or tissues; and more readily detect serious autoimmune disorders.

headline.main: Genetic Tests Offer Promise, but Raise Questions, Too

docs.abstract: Denise Caruso column on molecular diagnostic tests, which can give doctors more detailed information about patients, help them make more accurate diagnoses and more readily detect serious autoimmune disorders and help medical researchers; questions are being raised because there is no government requirement that tests offered by commercial labs must relate to particular disease or risk of disease in order to be sold to public; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: What I found most interesting in the response to Emily Bazelon's article (Jan. 21) was the absence of letters from women who have had an abortion. Considering the number who have had the procedure, it's worth noting how seldom they openly admit to it.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''REBA'' and ''THE O.C.'': rarely linked in life, they're now partners in death. ''Reba'' signs off after six seasons with back-to-back episodes on Sunday (CW, 7 and 7:30 p.m.) and ''The O.C.'' ends its fourth and last season on Thursday (Fox, 9 p.m.). The Texas sitcom and the California soap opera had more than a few things in common: divorce, alcoholism, unexpected pregnancy, careers in real estate and pop music. Life in suburban Houston and Newport Beach hasn't been so different after all. If you want to understand better the issues surrounding the Geneva Conventions, the Bush administration and American treatment of accused terrorists it holds captive, read the essay ''No Exit'' by Joseph Lelyveld, former executive editor of The New York Times, in the Feb. 15 issue of The New York Review of Books. If you want your anger stoked, watch Rory Kennedy's documentary ''GHOSTS OF ABU GHRAIB'' (HBO, 9:30 p.m. Thursday). Depending on your sympathies, you can be irritated by the way the not-quite-openly polemical film simplifies some of the larger questions about American involvement in Iraq, or you can be outraged by its eyewitness accounts of what went on in the Tier 1 cellblock at Abu Ghraib. Among Ms. Kennedy's interview subjects are former prisoners and former guards and interrogators, including several convicted in courts-martial on charges of mistreating prisoners. On the lighter side, the cumbersomely named talk show ''SIT DOWN COMEDY WITH DAVID STEINBERG'' returns for a second six-week season beginning Wednesday (TV Land, 10 p.m.), and Mr. Steinberg kicks it off with a big get: Jerry Seinfeld. And in Sunday's new episode of ''THE SIMPSONS,'' ''Springfield Up'' (Fox, 8 p.m.), Eric Idle reprises his role as the documentary maker Declan Desmond.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Emergency contraception was approved last fall by the Food and Drug Administration for sale without prescription. So it is disturbing to hear this safe and effective means for preventing pregnancy called a ''powerful drug'' by Deirdre McQuade of the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops Secretariat for Pro-Life Activities (''Catholic Hospitals And Rape Victims,'' letter, Feb. 11).

docs.lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (NBC) LAW & ORDER The all-too-real story of Adrienne Shelly, the 40-year-old actress and director who was founding hanging in her Greenwich Village office in November, gets ripped from the headlines in this episode, in which Detectives Green and Cassady try to prove that her death is anything but self-inflicted. Reza Salazar plays the workman who is eventually charged with her death.
